subsection.title: Predicates
subsection.p:
Consider this mathematical sentence: x \lt 5 .
x is a variable, the subject of the sentence.
is less than five is the predicate
A predicate is a property that a subject can have.
P(x) := x \lt 5
The value of P(x) is the value of the propositional function P at x.
Assigning a value to x makes P a proposition (it then has a truth value)

definition.p: The domain of discourse (or universe of discourse) is the collection from which variables can take values.
For example, if my predicate function is x is a student at WSU, the function has a different meaning if my universe of discourse is all college students versus all powers of 5

statement.p:
Determine the truth values of the following:
Let P(x) be the statement The word x contains the letter a.
P(elephant)
P(purple)
P(true)
P(false)
Let Q(x,y) be the statement x^2 + y^2 = 25.
Q(4,5)
Q(3,4)

definition.p: The universal quantification of P(x) is the statement that P(x) is true for all values of x in the domain of discourse. We write \forall x P(x)
An x value for which P(x) is false is called a counterexample
The existential quantification of P(x) is the statement that there is some value x in the universe of discourse for which P(x) is true. We write \exists x P(x)

example.statement:
Let P(x) be x^2 \ge 0. What is the truth value of \forall x P(x) if the domain is:
All real numbers
All complex numbers

ol.li: Since x^2 \ge 0 for all real numbers (what you learned in Algebra is true), this statement is true.
This is false. Let x = \sqrt{-1}. Then (\sqrt{-1})^2 = -1 \not\ge 0.

answer.p: We showed that \sqrt{-1} is a counterexample to the universal quanfication.

example.statement:
Let the domain be all real numbers. Find a counterexample to the following statements:
\forall x (x^2 \not= x)
\forall x (|x| \gt 0)
\forall x (x \gt 3 \vee x \lt 2)

statement.p: We can combine quantifers, where each variable might come from a different domain. Precedence of quantifiers is left to right.

What is the truth value of the following expressions where the domain is all real numbers:
\forall x \exists y ( xy = 5)
\exists x \forall y ( xy = 5)

definition.p:
The negation of quantifiers is found as follows:

eg  orall P(x) \amp\equiv \exists x 
eg P(x) 
eg \exists P(x) \amp\equiv  orall x 
eg P(x)
It might help to think not all... is equivalent to some... do. While there isn't one who... is the same as no one does....

note.p: Counterexamples to universal statements work because if \exists x \neg P(x) is true, then \neg \forall x P(x) is also true, that is, \forall x P(x) is false!

statement.p:
For each negation below, write the statement using quantifiers to confirm each is correct.
The negation of There exists a green horse is No horse is green.
The negation of All people wear hats is the statement Some person doesn't wear hats.
The negation of Nobody loves math is Someone does love math.
Find the negation of some drivers don't obey the speed limit..

If the universe of discourse is all people at the university, and P(x) is the statement x loves to drink coffee, express each statement in plain English:
\forall x P(x)
\exists x P(x)
\forall x \neg P(x)

Translate the statement into logical expressions using predicates, quantifiers, and logical connectives.
All of your friends are perfect.
Not everybody is your friend or someone is not perfect.
Consider the statement, There is a building on the campus of some college in the United States in which every room is painted white.

ol.li: Express the statement using quantifiers. Be sure to define your predicate functions and specify the domain of each variable.
Express the negation of the above logical quantified statement so that no negation is to the left of a quantifier.
Write the negation of the statement in plain English.

exercise.statement:
Translate these statements into English where F(x) is x is fast and A(x) is x is an athlete..
\forall x (A(x) \to F(x)
\forall x (F(x) \land A(x)
\exists x (F(x) \to A(x)
\exists x (A(x) \land \neg F(x)

Let C(x) denote the predicate x is in the correct place, let E(x) denote x is in excellent condition, and let T(x) denote x is a tool where the domain of each predicate is the set of objects in a garage. Translate each into plain English:
\exists x \neg C(x)
\exists x (T(x) \land \neg C(x))
\forall x (T(x) \to (C(x) \land E(x))
